Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Elucidating the Physical Origins of Creep in Cementitious Materials Towards Improved Prediction and Prescription of Creep-Resistant Binders

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Due to its low cost, ease of use, and performance, concrete is by far the most manufactured material in the world. However, a significant limitation is its tendency to creep over long durations. This is especially problematic in high-rise building, as undesirable creep deformations can involve expensive repairs, strengthening, or replacement, or can ultimately result in fracture and failure. The large time scales over which such deformations occur (years) make it challenging, if not impossible, to directly assess the creep propensity of concrete. To this end, numerous predictive models of creep have been suggested. However, most of them lack a sound physical basis and are heavily parameterized, which renders their predictions questionable at best, especially for new emerging binders in which ordinary portland cement is partially or fully replaced by more environment-friendly materials like fly ash, slag or limestone. This project aims to identify the physical origin of the creep in concrete to enable reliable long-term predictions of creep deformations. Based on this knowledge, new testing protocols will be studied, and creep-resistant cementitious binders will be identified. This research integrates multiple disciplines, including physics, material science, and civil engineering and will train a diverse group of students to multi-dimensional engineering.

To elucidate the physical origin of creep in concrete, and to discriminate, e.g., between the sliding or dissolution-precipitation mechanisms, this research relies on a combination of simulations. All simulations mutually feed into each others and capture the contribution of each of the relevant scales of cementitious binders. This bottom-up strategy starts from atomistic molecular dynamics coupled with topological constraint theory, culminates in continuum finite element simulations, and benefits from mesoscale modeling to ensure the hand-shake of all the considered spatial scales. Each simulation will be systematically informed, complemented, and validated by experiments, which comprise indentation, vertical scanning interferometry, and uniaxial creep tests. This interdisciplinary effort will identify the decisive variables (e.g., composition, nanostructure, and chemical instability) that render a material sensitive, or not, to long-term aging phenomena such as creep. Pioneering accelerated perturbation-based simulation methods will be evaluated, which will permit the study of long-term aging and degradation phenomena in amorphous materials rapidly. Finally, the project will contribute to reveal the link between bulk properties (chemical composition, structure) and surface properties (e.g., dissolution rates).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main objective of this project consists of revealing the physical origin of creep in cementitious materials while developing rapid and well controlled protocols to predict long-term creep deformations as a function of composition and microstructure to promote designing of more durable concretes and appropriate assessment of current deformation state of aging infrastructures.

This project consisted in a two-and-a-half-year period of data collection on several stress relaxation experiments, averaging a duration of two weeks for each test. Several trials were done prior to the actual data collection period in order to attain a proper calibration of the new testing setup created for this study. Specimens made of cement paste and mortar were produced with different water to cement ratios (w/c) and loaded at different ages to evaluate their time-dependent viscoelastic properties and their functional dependence on parameters such as the w/c, sand content, and aging.

This project has resulted in two manuscripts: (1) ?Effect of Strain History and Mixture Proportions on Early Age Cement Paste and Mortar Stress Relaxation? submitted to the Journal of Materials in Civil Engineering (Manuscript number MTENG-11405, under review on July 2020); and (2) ?Multi-Level Homogenization of Concrete Viscoelastic Properties? already accepted for publication in the Proceedings of the ASME 2020, International Mechanical Engineering Congress and Exposition IMECE2020 (Manuscript number IMECE2020-24268). Another journal paper (3) is in development but has been postponed for the Fall 2020 semester due to the Covid-19 outbreak, which delayed the corresponding experiments.

The studies developed under this project are expected to contribute to the overall effort of alleviating the challenges involved in assessing concrete creep experimentally by focusing on assessing time-dependent viscoelastic properties of cement paste, which may be used as inputs to computationally upscale and simulate concrete creep behavior. Concrete is composed of aggregates, known for their linear elastic nature, dispersed in a viscoelastic cement paste that exhibits ongoing creep during the course of its lifespan. Hence, the creep behavior of concrete should be completely characterized by the cement paste.

The study described in the journal paper (1) consisted in performing stress relaxation tests to evaluate the sensitivity of the early age relaxation modulus to the strain history and to quantify its functional dependence on loading age, w/c and sand content. A deep understanding on the influence of these parameters on time-dependent behavior of cement materials is essential to the efforts of developing materials tailored with optimized viscoelastic properties to best suit their purpose and application. In addition, an accurate assessment of these intrinsic material properties is critical to the reliability of multi-scale models used in predicting long-term concrete behavior at the macroscale. The study described in the conference paper (2) is a first effort on upscaling cement paste data to simulate mortar behavior. Reasonable results were obtained and further improvement of the method is suggested. Ongoing work (3) focuses on improving these method (2) and further use simulated mortar data to simulate concrete behavior.

The key outcomes for this project are: 1) stress relaxation tests require careful quantification of strain fields in the constitutive equation upon calculations of the relaxation modulus as the strain history has shown to greatly affect the shape and magnitude of the relaxation modulus; 2) in contrast to general understanding of the effect of w/c on creep, cement pastes with lower w/c and loaded at very early ages exhibit greater relaxation than higher w/c cement pastes; 3) the influence of w/c and sand content on the rate of relaxation significantly decreases with aging and simpler methods to account for these effects are suggested.

These findings will enhance the understanding of the mechanisms dictating the viscoelastic behavior of cement materials, promoting the development of better prediction models, stimulating more effective design practices for new infrastructure with longer service life and contributing to a more accurate assessment of current conditions of aging infrastructure.

Modified by: Zachary Grasley
